column41: Located about 9 km north of Lufeng at the southern side of Miaoshanpo-Mountain; IVPP-Point 75033 called section D.
column59: Quarry sequence is divided into 8 beds (numbered from top) in the Xi River Basin north of Lufeng China. These unconformably overly Mesozoic sediments. No Formation names are given.\r\nHan 1985: "Its geological age is Late Miocene equivalent to the Turolian of European sequence of land mammal ages." Qi 1986: Age "8 Ma or perhaps a bit later"
column60: Quarry section at Lufeng is 8 m thick. Detailed microstratigraphy given in Qi 1985 and Badgley et al 1988.

column104: does NOT include numerous small mammal specimens reported by Russell 1972 to be from "Rodent Hill V-37"\nsaid to be late Whitneyan but much of this suggests a Geringian age to me: JA 24.1.97

includes KU-MT-44 (Tavenner Ranch loc. 4) and probably several other localities: see Pierce and Rasmussen 1992
uncomformably overlies welded tuff dated at 29.5 +/- 2.8 Ma (FT on zircon) but uncomformity is shown to be considerable and error is large: Tedford et al. 1987
faunal lists of Douglass (1903) and Riel (1964) are stratigraphically mixed but most or all of the records correspond to Rasmussen i.d.s for the Lower Cabbage Patch including: Meniscomys sp. "? Mesocyon drummondensis" - confirmed as included in Rasmussen list by Wang 1994 Kukusepasutanka schultzi - the type from "Hellgate River 3 miles east of Drummond Granite County": Macdonald 1956b Diceratherium cf. armatum "Promerycochoerus" minor type - from KU Mt-33 lower Cabbage Patch beds: Stevens and Stevens 1996 "Leptomeryx transmontanus" - type of Douglass 1903 is from "east of Drummond on Hellgate River": Frick 1937 "Desmatochoerus macrosynaphus" - type is from KU Mt-31 same level as Mt-33: Stevens and Stevens 1996
"? Parasminthus sp." is not documented in North America see Korth 1994c
"at least" NISP counts are probably not severe underestimates and NISP estimate of 730 seems reasonable
NISP 5

column60: "The channel base contains large pebbles up to 10 cm in diameter. Above the pebbly layer is the main fossiliferous bed. It is about 30 cm thick and is gravelly. Above it is a layer of strongly cemented concretions. Each concretion is about 20 to 30 cm long and nearly 10 cm thick. These concretions are interpreted as the result of later water table action. They contain fossils as do several centimeters of the overlying layer."

column103: Tihen collection is later than the original ones
column104:
based on discussion of Tedford et al. 1987 this is above the Martin Canyon Beds sensu stricto which includes the Merycochoerus Quarry (see) and is equivalent to "horizon D" of Matthew
Galbreath implies that Merychyus elegans of Schultz and Falkenbach 1947 ("M. paniensis" referred of Loomis 1924) from near "Pawnee Butte" is from the Martin Canyon equivalent shown in his fig. 8
specimen counts for Insectivora and Rodentia based on Wilson other taxa on Galbreath 1953
generically determinate NISP 333
Galbreath 1953 indicates the presence of a "Merychippus" - grade form and of a chalicothere both omitted by later authors; Galbreath does indicate that the chalicothere may be from younger sediments; Coombs 1998 describes Moropus material from "Martin Canyon," but this may be from Merycochoerus Quarry

in a normal zone; based on FT zircon date of 6.8 +/- 0.2 Ma this should be C & K 92 zone C3Bn (old C6N) NOT old upper zone C5N contra MacFadden et al. 1979; FT date also is supported by correlation by Perkins 1998 of this ash with the Blacktail Creek ash bed dated at 6.7 +/- 0.10 Ma in Idaho by K-Ar; this correlation is confirmed by Passey et al. 2002 who report a revised Ar/Ar date of 6.62 Ma for the Idaho ash

in terminology of Morlan 1984 Unit 2 is the middle part of Unit 2a and Unit 1b is the basal zone of Unit 2a
Morlan 1984 gives generally compatible lists of microtines from OCR 11 and OCR 44

column41: 1 km to the NE of Khristos (Christos) in the Strimon Basin
column59: within MN 10
column60: A polymict poorly sorted conglomerate containing pebbles of schist gneiss and granite. This coarse-grained series grades upwards into arkosic sands and finally into clays with occasional lignites. Within the top part of the formation two "landslide" breccias occur. The lower of these consists of metamorphic rocks the upper one of granite.
column94: teeth

column41: On the southern slope of Somleu Hill near the village of Betfia (county Bihor).
column59: Cave deposit. The abundance of Mimomys species and the appearance of two primitive species of arhizodont arvicolids make it possible to place this fauna at the beginning of the Biharian (Early Pleistocene Eburonian). The large number of Villanyian survivors justifies such a dating. Is subsequent to the first Eburonian cooling and probably corresponds to a warming phase in the middle of this glacial complex.
column60: A calcareous slightly cemented breccia with terra-rossa accumulated in a karstic fissure.
column73: A calcareous slightly cemented breccia with terra-rossa accumulated in a karstic fissure.
column103: Caves discovered between 1966 and 1991 and excavated by the Bucharest Speleological Institute and the "Tarii Crisurilor" Museum of Oradea.
column104: Contains some thermophilous forms such as Macaca sylvana cf. florentina and a species of flying squirrel is subsequent to the first Eburonian cooling and probably corresponds to a warming phase in the middle of this glacial complex.

column41: SE from Auch near Castelnau-Barbarens. Coordinates are for Sansan about 8 km SW from Castelnau-Barbarens.
column60: The fossils come from different superposed lithologies. Those include: purple clays gray clays marls but also limestones and molasse. No distinction is made about the exact provenance of the fossils from these various levels.
column104: The ref. Ginsburg (1964)is an update of previous works (Lartet 1836-1858) and Filhol (1891) but it was published as new excavations were taking place.

column41: On the southern slope of Somleu Hill near the village of Betfia (county Bihor).
column59: Fewer members of the genus Mimomys prevalence of arhizodont arvicolids plus the primitive and homogenous morphology of Microtus has led site to be dated on biostratigraphic grounds to the Lower Waalian (~1.4-~1.3Ma). Abundance of Muridae and the occurence of Glirulus pusillus are in any case evidence of a temperate phase.
column60: Accumulated in a small entirely silted cave near the village of Betfia opened by quarrying for Cretaceous limestone.

column41: approx. 7 km N of Lefkon
column59: may be the same level as Ano Metochi 2-3
column60: A polymict poorly sorted conglomerate containing pebbles of schist gneiss and granite. This coarse-grained series grades upwards into arkosic sands and finally into clays with occasional lignites. Within the top part of the formation two "landslide" breccias occur. The lower of these consists of metamorphic rocks the upper one of granite.

column41: inside a cave from Podlesice near Kroezyce in Central Poland
column59: Pliocene-Pleistocene unit corresponds to Gunz-Mindel Interglacial (in early refs) the bone breccia includes both in-situ and specimens from a dump-pile no stratigraphy is discernable but the in-situ bed is only 4m in thickness. Kowalski 1962 (Ref 8869) revises age to just Pliocene so not from the interglacial. Later authors put age at Middle Pliocene (from 1963 on). Assigned to mammalian zone MN 14 (Ref 9172 1989).

column103: 500 kg of rock collected

column41: On the southern slope of Somleu Hill near the village of Betfia (county Bihor).
column59: Site overview: The site of Betfia 7 has a height of 8m and encompasses four complexes of layers. The first three of these represent the filling of a former cave containing numerous fragments of speleotherms and the last is made up of loess-like deposits accumulated in subaerial conditions. Level 1a is the basal complex in the cave fillings and contains cracked stones. This level contains Lemmus and has been referred to a cooling phase probably contemporaneous with the middle Waalian. (= Middle Lower Pleistocene approx. 1.3Ma).
column60: Level 1a is the basal complex in the cave fillings containing speleotherm fragments and cracked stones.
column103: sites discovered between 1966 and 1991 and excavated by the Bucharest Speleological Institute and the "Tarii Crisurilor" Museum of Oradea.

column59: Site overview: The site of Betfia 7 has a height of 8m and encompasses four complexes of layers. The first three of these represent the filling of a former cave containing numerous fragments of speleothemes. Levels 1b-e have been dated to the late Waalian (MIddle Lower Pleistocene approx. 1.2-1.15Ma).
column60: the filling of a former cave containing numerous fragments of speleothemes.
column103: Sites discovered between 1966 and 1991 and excavated by the Bucharest Speleological Institute and the "Tarii Crisurilor" Museumn of Oradea.
column104: Taking into account on the one hand the progressive dental structure of Microtus pliocaenicus and Prolagurus praepannonicus and on the other the high frequency of Glirids and the emergence of some thermophilus species we have ascribed the middle and upper parts of this sequence of strata (levels 1b-e) to an interval with a milder climate corresponding to the late Waalian.

column41: On the southern slope of Somleu Hill near the village of Betfia (county Bihor).
column59: Late Menapian (=Late Lower Pleistocene approx. 1.05-1.00Ma)
column103: Sites discovered between 1966 and 1991 and excavated by the Bucharest Speleological Institute and the "Tarii Crisurilor" Museum of Oradea
column104: A rich fauna characterised by a marked turnover due both to the presence of immigrants among the large mammals and to accelerating evolutionary changes in the different lineages of rodents. The high frequency of Leporidae Cricetidae and lagurines the prevalence of the genus Microtus and the scarcity of forest species lead us to assign this fauna to a dry phase. The evolutionary level allows us to place it in the late Menapian.

column41: on the southern slope of Somleu Hill near the village of Betfia (county Bihor).
column59: Site overview: the site of Betfia 7 has a height of 8m and encompasses four complexes of layers. The first three of these represent the filling of a former cave containing numerous fragments of speleothemes. Level 3 is formed of three layers of clay with speleothemes. Level 3a is dated to the Late Menapian/early Bavelian on arvicolid morphology (= Late Lower Pleistocene approx. 1.0Ma).

column103: Sites discovered between 1966 and 1991 and excavated by the Bucharest Speleological Institute and the "Tarii Crisurilor" Museum of Oradea
column104: The composition of rodent faunas evokes a steppe environment with isolated enclaves of forest in a warm and dry climate of Mediterranean aspect.

column41: On the southern slope of Somleu Hill near the village of Betfia (county Bihor).
column59: Site overview: the site of Betfia has a height of 8m and encompasses four complexes of layers. The last (level 4) is made up of loess-like deposits accumulated in sub-aerial conditions. Level 4 comprises two layers of loess separated by a fossil soil. Level 4a is the first loess level and is correlated with Glacial A of the Cromerian (= Early Middle Pleistocene approx. 0.7Ma)
column73: The last (level 4) is made up of loess-like deposits accumulated in sub-aerial conditions. Level 4 comprises two layers of loess separated by a fossil soil. Level 4a is the first loess level.
column103: SItes discovered between 1966 and 1991 and excavated by the Bucharest Speleological Institute and the "Tarii Crisurilor" Museum of Oradea.
column104: Level 4a has remarkable faunal diversity with Mimomys savini Microtus gregaloides and a high frequency of Bison schotensacki and the first emergence of Microtus agrestis Ursus deningeri and Mammuthus trogontherii.

column41: On the southern slope of Somleu Hill near the village of Betfia (county Bihor).
column59: Site overview: the site of Betfia has a height of 8m and encompasses four complexes of layers. The last (level 4) is made up of loess-like deposits accumulated in sub-aerial conditions. Level 4 comprises two layers of loess separated by a fossil soil. Level 4a is the first loess level and is correlated with Glacial A of the Cromerian (= Early Middle Pleistocene approx. 0.7Ma)
column73: The last (level 4) is made up of loess-like deposits accumulated in sub-aerial conditions. Level 4 comprises two layers of loess separated by a fossil soil. Level 4a is the first loess level.
column103: SItes discovered between 1966 and 1991 and excavated by the Bucharest Speleological Institute and the "Tarii Crisurilor" Museum of Oradea.
column104: Level 4a has remarkable faunal diversity with Mimomys savini Microtus gregaloides and a high frequency of Bison schotensacki and the first emergence of Microtus agrestis Ursus deningeri and Mammuthus trogontherii.

column41: "the Lakhuti outcrop is situated north-east of Kuliab on the right bank of the Obimasar river near Lakhuti village". The Lakhuti 2 localities are at the mouth of the Khoshar brook a tributary of the Obimasar. Lakhuti 2 point is 100m along the brook on the right bank.
column59: "the mammal remains originate fro the silty inter-layers of the pebble-silty desposits of the Kayrubak suite". At Lakhuti 2 point the bones are found in grey-green lake silts with plant remains and freshwater molluscs. Bones are scattered throughout the layer within a height of 1-2m. No date given thought to be Early Pleistocene.
column60: Bones found in grey-green lake silts with plant remains and freshwater molluscs. Scattered throughout the layer within a height of 1-2m.
column73: Bones found in the Kayrubak suite which unconformably overlies Lower Pliocene red sandstones and underlies thick Pleistocene loesses containing many fossil soil horizons.
column94: Bones are scattered in a layer 1-2m deep. "They are dark in colour and slightly ferruginated". In a 3m long lense full of carnivore coprolites rodent remains were found.
column103: Plant remains and freshwater molluscs are recorded from the site of Lakhuti 2 point but names are not given. Fossils were discovered in the 1950s and excavated from 1968 onwards by the Physics Institute the Geological Institute and the Palaeontological Institute the USSR Academy of Sciences and the Institute of Zoology and Parasitology the TajikSSR Academy of Sciences,

column41: near el-Latamne village in the middle course of the Orontes river valley 39km north of Hama.
column59: archaeological and palaeontological finds from different levels in a variety of small quarries Clark's main excavation site was near Miramil quarry. Middle Acheulean tools site dated to Middle Pleistocene predating 0.6Ma. fauna found in lower gravels.
column94: pollen is likely to have been transported in the river and by wind therefore the forest and arid environments represented by the pollen may have been some distance from the site.
column103: Latamne terrace QIII was created in a dry phase. The fauna indicates that the plateau had open steppe vegetation (horses giraffes etc.) while the river valley had lush vegetation (Hippopotamus Bos).

column41: Collections were made between the rivers Bitug and Don near the villages Antipovka and Chugunovka in the Voronezh district. The villages are only approx. 1km apart.
column59: Middle Pliocene
column60: on the floor there are chalks of the Cenomaninan they are overlain by sand beds 5 m to 20 m thick. The lower part of them contains gravel and coarse sand in the upper they are interbedded by middle- and fine-grained sands with crossbedding typical of river sediments.

column41: inside a cave from Podlesice near Kroezyce in Central Poland
column59: Pliocene-Pleistocene unit corresponds to Gunz-Mindel Interglacial (in early refs) the bone breccia includes both in-situ and specimens from a dump-pile no stratigraphy is discernable but the in-situ bed is only 4m in thickness. Kowalski 1962 (Ref 8869) revises age to just Pliocene so not from the interglacial. Later authors put age at Middle Pliocene (from 1963 on). Assigned to mammalian zone MN 14 (Ref 9172 1989).
column60: fossils collected in a bone breccia filling a small karstic hole inside a cave in Jurassic limestone fossils occur in clay matrix representing the floor of the cave
column94: some elements parautochthonous (bats thought to have inhabited the cave) others washed in (rodent teeth) and still others from owl pelets (small mamals reptiles)
column103: 500 kg of rock collected

column41: 20km south of Liege at the southwestern end of Sprimont commune. The site is on the right side of the River Ambleve south of Fraiture approx. 2km from the confluence of the Ambleve and the Ourthe rivers near Comblain-au-Pont.
column59: "the cave appears in cross-section in the upper face of the Quarry called La Belle-Roche". Six levels identfied within the cave deposits two of which contain faunal remains - 3 "Unsorted silty detrital complex" and 4 "Clay-calcite run-off complex". Four galleries have been found only Gallery one lacks fauna and archaeology. Dated later than the Brunhes/Matuyama boundary (0.78Ma) and before 0.35Ma (the limit of Uranium/Thorium dating). Thought to be c.0.5Ma on faunal grounds. OIS stage 13 to (perhaps)15.
column60: Level 3 : "silty but progressively loaded from bottom to top wuith reddish decalcification clay and limestone rock fragments". Occasional reworked concretions probably a secondary mud flow deposits. Bones found from bottom to top rarely in anatomical position.\r\nLevel 4: "a complex of very thin interbedded layers of calcite clay and clayey silt as well as a variable succession of laminar calcitic deposits and clayey run-off deposits" Lower layers contain lenses of microfauna particularly Chiroptera. Higher levels are sterile. Laid down in a very humid period.
column73: Karstic cave complex orientated East-West along "the stratification of carboniferous limestone beds".
column94: some movement of artefacts - graviational displacement and reworking within the cave.
column103: By 1990 400m2 of rock excavated in salvage operations.
column104: Faunal remains are reported from 2 different levels but the faunal list given here is for the site as a whole. Layer 3 is aperiod of climatic transistion from cold and continental (glacial) in the lowest level (3a) to warming sylvan species and large numbers of chiroptera in 3c and level 4. Pollen data also confim this.\r\nlist includes unidentified fish and frog remains.

column41: On the eastern border of the Sierra de Quibas in Abanilla.
column59: site is the filling of a karstic cavity the majority of specimens were collected from the ground surface. Two levels in the lower part of the detritic sequence are very rich in fossils. Dated using microfauna to between 1.3-1.0Ma.
column73: site is filling of a karstic cavity in Liassic limestones
column103: Site found in 1994 by the "Grupe Cultural Paleontologico de Elche" (Alicante)
column104: fauna reflects the area around the cavity - rocky with brushwood areas but some species indicate the presence of woods and humid areas. A dry palaeoclimatic regime pehaps a little wetter and warmer than the present.

column41: south of Casablanca city

column60: 'a calcareous sandstone deposited in a lacustrine or marshy environment'

column41: South of Casablanca
column59: Middle Pleistocene approx 0.4Ma. there are 13 different layers within the cave filling only one of which contains fauna (CGDR or continental 'Grotte des Rhinoceros'). This is a marine cave inhabited during a period of lower sea level at a time of relative aridity.
column73: GDR is a marine cave on an 'Anfatian' shoreline.
column94: 'the site appears to be a butchering location related to hunting/scavenging activities' (by Homo erectus).
column103: Discovered in 1991 in a working quarry. Stone tool assemblage contains several thousand artefacts.
column104: Abundant rhinoceros remains. Arid environment rodents and large grazing mammals suggest an open dry landscape.

column41: 1.5km south of Seydisehir.
column59: Fossils are from a fissure filling some 5m across in 'late Triassic bituminous limestones which outcrop in the northern foothills of the Taurus chain'. Mimomys - Arvicola association suggests (from European comparisons) a late Biharian date so site tentatively assigned to Middle Pleistocene. Ursus aff. deningeri is also present.
column104: Abundant small mammals. Collection also contains amphibians reptiles and birds. Specimens identified as Canid or Hyaenid indet. are also reported. Fauna suggests a humid and partly forested local environment with some permanent water.

column73: 'Four main depositional environments wewre recognised: 1. distal alluvial fan 2. fluvial channel 3. overbank and floodplain 4. pond environment. The main fossil beds occur in the floodplain and ponded deposits at levels that show the best developed paleosols.1
column104: Fauna adapted to relatively dry and open environments with some water as frogs and water shrews are present. Isotopic work indicates an open and probably steppic environment.

column60: 25cm thick layer with a silty matrix and decimetric clasts.

column41: co-ordinate based on the nearby town of La Union. Site located in the San Gines of the Jara mountains.

column73: 'During the Plio-Pleistocene the vertical karst of Messinian origin gave rise to cave openings to the exterior which became filled with bone-bearing breccia.'

column41: In the Sierra de Atapuerca 14km east of Burgos Northern Spain
column59: level TD4 has been dated after the Jaramillo event (0.99Ma) and before the Brunhes/Matuyama boundary (0.78) and is therefore late Lower Pleistocene.
column103: 'on the basis of pollen analysis a forested landscape dominated TD4 times with Quercus and Pinus. The presence of leafy deciduous trees (Fagus Betula Juglans Ulmus) and Olea indicate a transition between cold and warm conditions.'

column41: near to road N324 (Guadix-Jaen) SE from the town of Moreda and about 5km from the town of Darro (on which the co-ordinates are based).
column59: Late Pliocene Alfambrian MN15. Depth of stage 1 deposit is 1.7m.
column60: 1.7m thick of clayish material cemented towards its basal part and including other coarse-grained elements and limestone blocks.
column73: Infillings of the karstic fissures formed in the Liasic limestones in the last spurs of the Sierra Harana (External zone of the Cordillera Betica).
column94: 'there is plenty of fauna and although bones do not appear in order they are very well preserved.'

column41: Near to road N324 (Guadix-Jaen) SE from the town of Moreda and about 5km from the town of Darro (on which the co-ordinates are based).
column59: Late Pliocene Alfambrian MN15.
column60: 'It is formed by 2.20m for basically fine grained laminated clayish material.' These contain manganese and iron oxides which produce blue and grey tones and infill small bioturbation traces (roots or animals). 'The deposit shows a banding where there is an alternation between clay layers with very few remains and layers very rich in fossil remains.'
column73: 'infillings in the karstic fissures formed in the Liasic limestones in the last spurs of Sierra Harana (External zone of the Cordillera Betica).'
column94: In the fossil rich layers 'the remains are orientated parallel to the stratification in a dominant direction. They are well preserved without any sign of transport. It was probably formed by underwater decantation of low-energy waters. Next to the longbones there are mandibles skulls etc. Little gatherings with very complete skeletons can be seen and they look like fossil owl pellets. The burial must have been very quick.'

column41: Near to road N324 (Guadix-Jaen) SE from the town of Moreda and about 5km from the town of Darro (on which the co-ordinates are based).

column41: near to road N324 (Guadix-Jaen) SE from the town of Moreda and about 5km from the town of Darro (on which the co-ordinates are based).
column59: Late Pliocene MN16. Stage 4 is 'Sideways to previous deposits'.
column60: 'a breccia of angular limestone pebbles of decimetrical size included in a cemented clayish matrix.' The remains are disordered around the pebbles and are infilled with a layer of clay and another concentric one of limestone.'
column73: Breccia. 'infillings in the karstic fissures formed in the Liasic limestones in the last spurs of Sierra Harana (External zone of the Cordillera Betica).'
column94: 'its has less fauna than the other stages in the deposit and the remains appear in disorder sometimes occupying the holes between the blocks.'

column41: near to road N324 (Guadix-Jaen) SE from the town of Moreda and about 5km from the town of Darro.
column59: Late Pliocene MN15.
column60: 'it is made up of an alternation of red clayish levels cemented by carbonate materials that display a minimum thickness of 1.78m. The clayish level (from 2-6cm thick) contains faunal remains. It includes some calcareous detritic elements of centimetric size. The other levels are cemented carbonate materials thatt also include centimetric limestone pebbles. These levels do not contain fauna. There are some fractures that affect the deposit and are filled with clayish materials that are very rich in micromammals. To the top an erosive stage is noticeable which was later sealed by a stalagmite crust. This alternation of levels is named Mo1L-1; it is so compacted that it is very difficult to extract the fossils.'
column73: 'infillings in the karstic fissures formed in the Liasic limestones in the last spurs of Sierra Harana (External zone of the Cordillera Betica).'
column94: the longbones in the clayish levels with micromammal remains show a preferential direction parallel to the stratification.
column103: the material is so compacted that the specimens are very scarce and fragmented.

column41: near to road N324 (Guadix-Jaen) SE from the town of Moreda and about 5km from the town of Darro (on which the co-ordinates are based).
column59: Late Pliocene MN16.
column60: stage 3 (including Mo1L-3 and Mo1L-4) is made up of cemented clayish material that towards the central part include angular blocks of material from the previous deposits and from the surrounding rock. The part with thinner materials (i.e. not so brecciated) is called Mo1L-4 and has a variety of faunal remains.
column73: 'infillings in the karstic fissures formed in the Liasic limestones in the last spurs of Sierra Harana (External zone of the Cordillera Betica).'
column94: 'large amounts of remains were found and their distribution was very uniform in the sediment. The bones are not articulated but they are not broken. In general they look like a gathering due to owl pellets.'

column41: near to road N324 (Guadix-Jaen) SE from the town of Moreda and about 5km from the town of Darro (on which the co-ordinates are based).

column41: In the western margin of the Guadix-Baza basin 1km to the left of the road leading from Huelago to the railway station.
column59: Date: MN16b Late Villafranchian Plio-Pleistocene boundary Villanyian/Biharian. The Huelago section is 67m thick. The site occurs at the base of the carbonate span of the upper unit built up by a set of siltstones and lacustrine carbonates that crop out extensively in the surroundings of the site.
column60: At the top a 2-15m stetch of palustrine facies is developed. This stretch contains the Huelago Road site and is made up of a succession of a) massive and thinning upwards silty sands with intraclasts at its base and b) grayish-greenish silts with gastropods ostracods small bivalves and several cycled root-marks that evolve to calcrete levels.
column94: Most large mammal bones were highly fragmented and unidentifiable (total of 714 fragments 387 indet.)
column103: Excavated in 1984. Four pits were dug - A (14m2) B (14m2) C (18m2) and D (12m2) D is some 5m further down the slope and contained fewer bones than the others (175 187 285 and 67 specimens respectively). All pits were 2.9-3m deep.
column104: The mollusc and fish records have been sub-divided into levels within the site but the macromammal list has not. This is the composite mammal list and includes micromammals (also subdivided but only into levels e.g. level 4 could be associated with mollusc layer 4a 4b or 4c (or all of them)). Individual levels have been entered separately for molluscs and fish (see subcollections).

column41: Co-ordinates based on the town of Lannemezan which is nearby.
column59: Rodents indicate a date at the end of the Middle Villafranchian the rest of the fauna indicates Lower Pleistocene end Tiglian. So Plio-Pleistocene boundary MN17-MNQ1 Villanyian-Biharian.
column73: 'une vaste poche de 13m de hauteur actuelle ouverte prés du sommet colline. Aucune stratigraphie n'est visible les différents éléments ayant été soutirés vers de la bas de la poche. Le remplissage argileux rougeâtre renferme de petits éléments altérés du flysch albien voisin souvent bréchifiés des fragments de calcite roulée (réseau karstique disparu) des blocs calcaire peu émoussés (Cryergie?) et quelques témoins d'un remplissage antérieur sableux.' No visible stratigraphy but a mix of sediments including one sandy layer and some calcite blocks.
column94: The majority of large mammal remains are highly fragemented and cannot be identified to species. The material was largely collected through wet-sieving resulting in the bones of a large number of small and medium sized animals.
column104: the faunal assemblage indicates the change from a cold to warm phase at the end of the Tiglian.

column41: Site is north of the village of Baza (or Cullar-Baza) Co-ordinates based on the village of Zujar.
column59: Miocene Late Turolian MN13.

column41: Site is in the region of Huescar village on which the co-ordinates are based.
column59: Lower/MIddle Pleistocene Biharian approx. 0.9Ma but suggested by Garcia et al (1999) to be 0.7Ma.
column103: Some material stored in the Museo de Ciencias Naturales (MNCN) Madrid.
column104: Also has some redeposited Foraminifera (not named).

column41: Site in a quarry between the towns of Ptolemais and Kozani in Macedonia. Co-ordinates based on the town of Ptolemais.
column59: Pliocene Early Ruscinian MN14. 'The A-P-K basin is part of a graben system running in a NW-SE direction from Bitola (Yugoslavia) to Servia. It is suggested that Quaternary faulting caused the fractioning into the Bitola-Florina the A-P-K and the Kozani-Servia sub-basins.' The Neogene and Pleistocene deposits have been divided into three series the Basal Series the Coal Containing Series (subdivided into a. main field beds b. intermediate sequence and c. south field beds) and the Top Series. 'The main field consist of about 30metres of lignite with intercalations of calcareous muds and lignitic clays. The number and the thicknesses of these intercalations vary from locality to locality. The lignite is well layered and contians a few macroscopic plant remains xylite is rare. The coal beds contain a variable amount of clay. Molluscs are abundantly present in many coal beds. Intercalated calcareous beds have thicknesses of up to 0.5m; most beds are rich in molluscs and some contain root imprints. A 10 to 20cm thick level of yellowish sand is present in both mines and observed in most boring. This guide level is called layer 9 by the local miners. The site is in the Main field bed about 8m above layer 9 and 'is a lens within the lignite it has a thickness of 20cm and a horizontal extension of 4 metres.'
column60: 'It consists of coal particles molluscs and vertebrate remains in a clayey matrix and grades upwards into thinly layered black lignitic clay with abundant fishbones on the bedding planes.'
column73: 'The palynology of the Ptolemais lignites points to a depositional environments of reed-marshes and swamps with or without some clumps of trees.'
column94: 'The Kardia and Ptolemais faunas may be the undigested remains of the meals of some kind of heron which explains the association of fish frogs and small mammals.'
column103: Excavated in 1976 and 1977 by the State University of Utrecht and the Niedersachsisches Landesamt fur Bodenforschung Hannover.

column41: In the 'zona de Huescar y alrededores' (area round the locality of Huescar). Co-ordinates are based on the village of Huescar.
column59: Lower Pleistocene.

column41: Approximately 40km north of the town of Guadix. Co-ordiantes based on the town of Alamedilla.
column59: Late Pliocene Late Villafranchian MN16.

column41: This locality lies approximately 1.5km south of the village of Csarnota (on which the co-ordinates are based).'This locality lies in the westernmost part of the Villany mountains in southern Hungary on the flat ridge of Cserhegy and comprises pillars of red clay formed in limestone of the Middle Triassic.'
column59: Csarnotian stage Mid. Pliocene MN15 (according to Fejfar et al. 1997). Janossy puts it slightly later (in the Villanyian). Villafranchian.
column60: 'red clay.'
column103: This is a reconstructed faunal list including several collections excavated from 1910 onwards. The original site lists (1910-1930s) do not give exact locality info. but the later excavations uncovered 25 strata in a trench 1m x 1.5m and 3m deep.
column104: 'Two Pliogallus species described by Galliard have been deleted from the list.'

column41: This locality lies approximately 1.5km south of the village of Csarnota (on which the co-ordinates are based).'This locality lies in the westernmost part of the Villany mountains in southern Hungary on the flat ridge of Cserhegy and comprises pillars of red clay formed in limestone of the Middle Triassic.'

column41: Ostramos Hill rises insularly above the basin of the Upper Bodva between Tornazentandras and Bodvarako (on which the co-ordinates are based) as the northernmost member of the Rudabanya mountains (in the very north of Hungary).
column59: Mid Pliocene MN16 Villafranchian.
column60: 'This crevice was about 1-1.5m wide and as high as 30m. The upper part of the karstic formation was filled with dark red clay the lower with more yellowish clay occasionally cemented with calcite spots.'
column73: Locality 7 is a 'classical' tectonic fissure.
column103: Although layers were observed in the deposits 'commercial quarrying and the narrow width of the cleft' meant that collection by layer was not possible. It was excavated from1955 to 1975.

column59: Lower Pleistocene in text but is pre 2Ma in tables and is therefore late Pliocene.
column103: salvaged by Nosky in the autumn of 1952.

column41: Located in the Moyen-Atlas Mountains on the right bank of the Oued Sebou (river). Basin is roughly circular 4 km across and bounded by the Jebel Tizi-n-Zid to the south and by the Lias faults to the North and West.
column59: Terrestrial deposits are surrounded by Miocene marine deposits however no contact has been found. Base of terrestrial sequence is a basalt resting directly on Jurassic beds. The basalt is covered by a red volcanic formation (10-20 m thick) that has been dated to 9.7 +/- 0.5 Ma. Volcanic deposits are overlain by a series of lacustrine chalk ('calcaires') deposits (20-150 m thick). Fossil locality is from a small black clay lense rich in shells and small gastropods. This lense is located near the base of the chalk sequence.
column60: Small black clay lense rich in gastropods and shells. Located near base of lacustrine chalk sequence.
column73: Suggested that the volcanic flow led to the deposition of the lacustrine chalk deposits by limiting water flow. Thus fossil locality would be close in age to the basalt (9.7 Ma). This date matches well with biostratigraphic evidence.
column94: No information provided. Micromammals and small reptiles and birds only.
column103: No information on collection size.
column104: No abundance information available.

column41: Located 17 kilometers south of Guercif on the left embankment of the road from Guercif to Bourached.
column59: Road cuts into a lignite formation that has Miocene- aged marine deposits both above and below. A gray ash layer is located just above the level of the fossil locality.
column60: Lignite formation is ~ 2.5 meters thick and slightly inclined to the south.
column73: Gray ash layer located above the fossil locality can be correlated with a similar ash layer in the Melg-el-Ouidane formation (site of Camp Bertaux). Source of this ash is thought to be the Guilliz volcanoe and ash deposits have been dated to 7.4 +/- 1.2 Ma. This age correlates well with the fauna from this locality.
column94: No information available.
column103: Size of collection not known.
column104: No abundance information available.

column41: The flat Szolohegy of Beremend is situated about 9km south of the Villany mountains and the village of Villany (on whoch the co-ordinates are based).
column59: Janossy's lower Pleistocene begins at ~2.5Ma therefore they have been entered into the database as Pliocene.
column60: a cleft filled with red clay.
column73: A large number of carp and desmans indicating aquatic sediments.
column94: many of the bones show signs of having been carried across stony substrates. Also a large number of crucian carp (Carassius) and desmans indicating aquatic sediments.
column103: Krolopp and myself savaged this material in the summer of 1973. 'During the course of very intensive quarrying mining engineer Mrs Kralik collected antilope remains (horncores parts of tooth rows fragments of limb bones) from a cleft filled with red clay which she presented to the Hungarian Natural History Museum. We paid a visit to the site on the receipt of the material and succeeded in obtaining for sedimentation a portion some kilograms in weight of an enormous block of red clay from the northwestern corner of the quarry.'

column41: On the northside of a quarry between the village of Villany and the railway station. Co-ordinates based on Villany village.
column59: Villany 3 is the type locality of the Villanyian fauna and is in the Upper Villanyian. Late Pliocene MN17.
column60: a 1m wide cleft running from east to west infilled with red sediment cemented by secondary calcite formation.
column73: 'The site is situated in the northern wall of the eastern end of the ridge quarry. A cleft on the average 1m wide and lying in a direction east to west cuts through the Lower Malm Oxfordian limestone and is filled with red sediment cemented by secondary calcite formation.'
column103: Kormos collected at this locality from the 1910s until 1939.
column104: The faunal lists contain no quantitative data and although collected layer-by-layer only one faunal list is given.

column41: Osztramos Hill rises insularly above the basin of the Upper Bodva between Tornaszentandras and Bodvarako (on which the co-ordinates are based) as the northenmost member of the Rudabanya mountains (in the very north of Hungary).
column59: MN17 Late Pliocene.
column60: 'The red clay sediment deposited in a cave formed by a cleft running northwest to southeast direction was blasted in 1971. At the time of palaeontological collections in 1969 and 1970 the upper part of the profile 10m high and 5-6m wide was made up of yellowish sediment closed downwards by a calcite shelf below which reddish brown sediment was found. The material was collected from 9 arbitrarily delimited (20-30cm wide) strata.'
column103: The material was collected from 9 arbitrarily delimited (20-30cm wide) strata. Analysis by layers has not been carried out so far. The faunal list is primarily from layers 2 and 3.

column41: on top of locality 5 in the northern wall of the quarry which is between the villlage of Villany and the railway station.
column59: Upper Villanyian MN17 same age as Osztramos 3.
column73: 'right above locality no. 3 a 10-20cm wide cleft with a corroded surface sinks into the karstic surface which at a depth of about 1.5-2.0m is cut by a horizontal shift...the rock of the cleft is Oxfordian limestone...and its direction coincides with the strike direction.'

column41: 'The locality comprises a quarry at the highest point of the Almasi Hill about 2km south of the village' (on which the co-ordinates are based).
column59: Upper Villanyian (Tornan substage) MN17 Late Pliocene.
column60: '1m of reddish-brown sandy and loessy fossil soil.'
column73: In 1975 'the free northwestern profile of the quarry stood at a height of about 10m with the lowermost 3m composed of freshwater limestone followed by 1m of reddish-brown sandy and loessy fossil soil and finally 5-6m of compact freshwater limestone.'
column103: Approximately 1 metric ton of fossil soil was collected and washed yielding 10 samples which have been combined in the faunal list. The fauna 'is unquestionably homogeneous because of its closure from below and above by freshwater limestone.'

column41: 'The locality comprises a quarry at the highest point of the Almasi Hill about 2km south of the village' (on which the co-ordinates are based).
column59: Upper Villanyian (Tornan substage) MN17 Late Pliocene.
column60: '1m of reddish-brown sandy and loessy fossil soil.'
column73: In 1975 'the free northwestern profile of the quarry stood at a height of about 10m with the lowermost 3m composed of freshwater limestone followed by 1m of reddish-brown sandy and loessy fossil soil and finally 5-6m of compact freshwater limestone.'

column41: Co-ordinates based on the town of Nagyharsany. 'parallel to the the main range of the Villany mountains some 2 km distance to the south is the 3km long narrow Nagyharsanyhegy 442m a.s.l. with soaring steep ledges to the south and north.' Locality 5 is in the main quarry (formerly called the 'Mauthner Quarry') and now demolished.
column59: probably Villanyian based on the presence of Pliovormela berememdensis. Late Pliocene.
column73: 'The southern slope and the ridge are very strongly karstic and the hill is composed of very steep in places almost vertical Mesozoic formations. The first of these are Anisian dolomite in the north which is followed by Callovian Cornbrash limestone (according to recent studies: Pliensbachian (Lower Jurassic) and then Callovian layers) then Lower and Upper Malm limestone then a sediment hiatus in which a bauxite formation is intercalated; finally Lower Cretaceous rocks on the southern slope of the hill. Here and there red clay containing bone remains fills the vertical clefs of the system of faults marring the hill.' (originally in Hungarian in Kretzoi (1956) translated into English by Janossy (1986).

column41: Co-ordinates based on the town of Nagyharsany. 'parallel to the the main range of the Villany mountains some 2 km distance to the south is the 3km long narrow Nagyharsanyhegy 442m a.s.l. with soaring steep ledges to the south and north.' Locality 5 is in the main quarry (formerly called the 'Mauthner Quarry') and now demolished.
column59: probably Villanyian based on the presence of Pliovormela berememdensis. Late Pliocene.
column73: 'The southern slope and the ridge are very strongly karstic and the hill is composed of very steep in places almost vertical Mesozoic formations. The first of these are Anisian dolomite in the north which is followed by Callovian Cornbrash limestone (according to recent studies: Pliensbachian (Lower Jurassic) and then Callovian layers) then Lower and Upper Malm limestone then a sediment hiatus in which a bauxite formation is intercalated; finally Lower Cretaceous rocks on the southern slope of the hill. Here and there red clay containing bone remains fills the vertical clefs of the system of faults marring the hill.' (originally in Hungarian in Kretzoi (1956) translated into English by Janossy (1986).

column59: Late Pliocene Betfian substage MN17.
column73: 'the 'main locality' situated in the eastern quarry of the hill which Kormos called the 'bone-brecciated pillar' and Kretzoi termed locality no. 2 of Nagyharsanyhegy. This residual pillar of the steeply slanted (and an angle of about 120-130 degrees) tectonically preformed karstic hollow embedded in Malm limestone has since been demolished but its continuation in the present layer of the quarry contained enough material for the author and colleagues to obtain smaller collections from 1973 to 1975 (presently known as the 'artist colony quarry').'
column103: Kormos collected there briefy in 1916 then Kretzoi and myself (Janossy) in 1953 and 1955 and the author and colleagues obtained smaller collections from 1973 to 1975.

column41: Osztramos Hill 'rises insularly above the basin of the Upper Bodva between Tornaszentandras and Bodvarako as the northernmost member of the Rudabanya mountains (in the very north of Hungary).'
column59: Middle/Late Lower Pleistocene similar age to Locality 8 between 1.5 and 1.0Ma.\r\nLocality 2 consisted of the filling of an enormous cave in the eastern portion of section XII of the quarry 320 a.s.l. 'The profile of cave filled entirely with red clay was 20m long by 14m high at discovery. About 2.5-3.5m above the basement two layers sloping towards the north were found to contain extreme accumulations of bones which we fully exploited and sedimented.'
column60: 'red clay.'
column103: The cave in question was opened in 1965 and totally blasted in 1969.
column104: The faunal list is from the lower layer the few large mammal finds were from mixed waste rock material.

column41: Osztramos Hill rises insularly above the basin of the Upper Bodva between Tornaszentandras and Bodvarako as the northernmost member of the Rudabanya mountains (in the very north of Hungary).
column59: Biharian Middle/Late Lower Pleistocene late Villafranchian. In the text it is dated to earlier than locality 2 on the evolutionary stage of Allophaiomys but in the tables it is later. Both locality 2 and 8 date between 1.5-1.0Ma. \r\n 'This locality lied at the foot of the north-eastern wall of section XII of the quarry about 50-60m north of Locality no. 2 in a portion of the quarry opened in November 1970.'
column60: 'red clay'
column73: The horizontal cave about 100m long is situated at an elevation of about 305m. At the very end of the hollow system red clay dug out of the cleft communicating with the cave was found to contain the locality no. 8 of vertebrate fossils.
column103: Most of the cave was blasted in 1972 and then exploited.

column41: Somssich Hill lies approximately 500m SW of the village of Villany (on which the co-ordinates are based). Locality 2 is on the northern slope of the hill near locality 1. 'situated about 9m east (90 degrees) of the southeastern-eastern corner of a press house itself about 50m east of elevation point 180.2m.'
column59: Late Lower Pleistocene Biharian.
column60: 'In contrast with similar localities in the Villany mountains this loessy sediment was definitely light yellow in colour.'
column73: 'the site was made up of a hollow filling left by quarrying of Malm (Oxfordian) limestone.'
column103: Excavated in 'layers in a 1 by 2m portion of the sediment in 1975. In the course of yearly excavations we reached a depth of 6m in 1981.'\r\n'to a depth of about 5m the homogeneous loess did not change its colour although from about 2m compact freshwater limestone (calcite) deposits impeded the work. Around a depth of 6m the sediment started changing colour to brownish-red. All the 20-30cm thick layers removed contained small vertebrate remains in statistically analysable quantities. Preliminary analysis of this material showed that the relative abundance of Pitymys arvalidens decreased from 65-75% in the upper layer to 4% in the lower layers while that of Lagurus increased to 65%. Further down the relative abundance of the two species became equal. Layer no. 29 slightly more reddish in colour contained the only primate specimen (Macaca sp.) whereas layer no. 30 similar in colour and consistency contained the only tooth remain of the lemming (Lemmus sp.).'
column104: This is a preliminary list disregarding stratification and based on several thousand finds.

column41: Somssich Hill lies approximately 500m SW of the village of Villany (on which the co-ordinates are based). Locality 2 is on the northern slope of the hill near locality 1. 'situated about 9m east (90 degrees) of the southeastern-eastern corner of a press house itself about 50m east of elevation point 180.2m.'
column59: Late Lower Pleistocene Biharian.
column60: 'In contrast with similar localities in the Villany mountains this loessy sediment was definitely light yellow in colour.'
column73: 'the site was made up of a hollow filling left by quarrying of Malm (Oxfordian) limestone.'
column103: Excavated in 'layers in a 1 by 2m portion of the sediment in 1975. In the course of yearly excavations we reached a depth of 6m in 1981.'\r\n'to a depth of about 5m the homogeneous loess did not change its colour although from about 2m compact freshwater limestone (calcite) deposits impeded the work. Around a depth of 6m the sediment started changing colour to brownish-red. All the 20-30cm thick layers removed contained small vertebrate remains in statistically analysable quantities. Preliminary analysis of this material showed that the relative abundance of Pitymys arvalidens decreased from 65-75% in the upper layer to 4% in the lower layers while that of Lagurus increased to 65%. Further down the relative abundance of the two species became equal. Layer no. 29 slightly more reddish in colour contained the only primate specimen (Macaca sp.) whereas layer no. 30 similar in colour and consistency contained the only tooth remain of the lemming (Lemmus sp.).'
column104: This is a preliminary list disregarding stratification and based on several thousand finds.

column41: In Meszkohegy Quarry between the village of Villany (on which the co-ordinates are based) and the railway station (to the north of the village).
column59: Biharian late Lower Pleistocene.
column60: 'terra rossa'
column73: 'the wide Oxfordian limestone of the southern wall is dissected by a vertical 1m wide cleft in the eastern upper portion of the large quarry of Mészoköhegy of Villany about 50m from locality no. 3 and is filled in its entire height by... terra rossa... and is very rich in fossils.' (originally published in Hungarian by Kretzoi (1956) translated into English in Janossy (1986)).
column94: 'Kormos collected samples here in 1931 Kretzoi and co-workers uncovered remains 'from the loose material among the strongly cemented parts' on which the faunal list is based. (i.e. not in-situ.)

column41: 'At the middle of the southern slope of the 'ridge quarry' of Villany about 10m west of locality no. 7 lies a cleft running in a north to south direction which continues downwards in a chimney-like cave about 1-1.5m in diameter.' (This chimney forms locality 8). Co-ordinates based on the village of Villany.
column59: Biharian Middle Pleistocene. The cave was opened from one side during quarrying and Kretzoi and his co-workers including the author (Janossy) in 1953 and 1955 removed material in 12 layers. The series starting from the bottom begins with reddish clay with large calcite deposits and in the upper layers is composed of limy loess formations.'
column60: 'limy loess formations'
column104: grassland-steppe environment.

column41: 'a small unused quarry located in the vicinity of Repashuta (on which the co-ordinates are based) in the Bukk mountains on a ridge between Kovesvarad and Zsindelyesteto about 50m south-southwest of the highway between Eger and Lillafured.'
column59: Biharian Middle Pleistocene
column60: 'orange sediment'
column73: 'A karstic pit about 5m high and 2-3m wide was found in compact Triassic Ladinian limestone in the northern corner of the quarry. This was filled with orange sediment .... washed almost in its entirety in 1957-58.'
column103: Discovered by Janossy in 1955. Different strata were not identified.\r\n
column104: forest environment.

column41: This locality is in the southwestern corner of the Meszkohegy quarry (between the village of Viallany (on which the co-ordinates are based) and the railway station) and 'comprises a small cleft running in a north to south direction about 10m east of locality no. 8.'

column103: 'the whole of the material of this locality was collected by Kretzoi in 1955.'

column59: Biharian Middle Pleistocene

column59: Three levels with fauna recorded the lower gravels (unteren Kiesen) The loam zone (Lehmzone) and the upper gravels (Oberen Kiesen). column41: Near the village of Póvoa de Santarém a lignitic clay with fragments of plants and bone were discovered when a well was dug. Coordinates from the Carte Militaire du Portugal 1:25,000 sheet no. 341 (Pernes Santarém) ND 211,5 558,5.
column59: The fossiliferous layer comes from approximately 10 meters below the surface. The presence of Anchitherium and absence of Hipparion excludes an Upper Miocene age. "..Megacricetodon crusafonti Fahlbuschia darocensis Cricetodon jotae are characteristic of mammalian MN6 unit thus their ageis is nearly that of Sansan and Manchones (however the presence of Peridyromys hamadryas and Lagopsis verus do suggest amidst this biozone a somewhat later age than Sansan's).."\n\nIndirect correlation with marine formations underlying oyster-bearing beds most probably in correspondance to the apogee of the same transgression that deposed near Lisbon "schlier" facies from VI-a division division (Serravalian Blow's zones 10-13 Globorotalia meyeri zone).
column60: lignitic mudstone
column73: Lignite suggests marsh/stagnant pond in the vicinity of a river or ?oxbow (reference is to dead arms "des bras morts). Differing biozones are cited for original habitats of specific taxa including savannah and forest invironments. \n
column94: Not endemic or autochthonous taxa. Reference to the small mammals having been transported by predators or by waters then a brook into the final resting pond.
column103: In the collections of the Centro de Estratigrafia e Paleobiologia das Universidades de Lisboa.\r\n\r\nThe intial report on the lignitic clays is from a report on the geology "Servico de Fomento Mineiro" M. Valdemiro B. Pereira M. G. Zbyszewski the bone fragments. Antunes and Mein collected additional sediment that was subsequently "washed" to recover the fossils.

column60: Below a layer 15 cm in thickness which is strongly weathered is a layer of light-brown marl 120 cm thick which nearly contains all of the vertebrate fossils. Below that layer there is a small (15 cm) layer of limestone with big Gastropods (Galactochilus sp.). They are followed by 20-25 cm of colloured marls where are only found single bone-fragments and teeth-fragments. Below that are clay- and sandlayers without fossils.\r\n
column94: mainly teeth
column104: Also found were a lot of Gastropods like Planorbis and Cepaea.

column32: La Pietris Tetoiu 1 lower faunal horizon
column41: Between Tetoiu (on which co-ordinates are based) and Irimesti (9km apart) in the Oltet river valley on the western slope of a hill named Dealul Viilor. 3km north of Valea Roscai.
column59: Late Pliocene just before the Olduvai event (based on palaeomagnetism). Faunal comparison indicates that the Lower Faunal Horizon (Tetoiu 1) correlates with the upper part of the Khaprov faunal complex upper MN17 (St Vallier Zone) probably equivalent to the Tiglian warm stage. Fauna at La Pietris is dominated by equids suggesting a more continental climate (drier and cooler) possibly a cooler oscillation of the Tiglian.\r\n\r\n About 92m below the top of the section in 'a sequence of sands and fine sands 2m thick.'
column60: 'a sequence of sands and fine sands 2m thick.'
column73: The lower faunal horizon is in an approximately 20m thick bed consisting 'predominantly of silty sands and sand levels with gravels and larger pebbles were also observed. These beds are rich in faunal remains.' 'The beds have an average dip of 1 to 2 degrees SE.'

column59: In the Baraolt Basin Brasov Depression. Middle Pleistocene 'Cromerian complex'. Roughly equivalent to Tarko layers 10-5 Hundsheim Mosbach main level St. Esteve Janson layers F-G and Westbury 'Rodent earth'. Cool temperate wet climate interrupted at the base by a steppe interval (lower upper level 1). 'A polygonal ground indicating periglacial conditions superposed by remnants of a red fossil soil are intercalated between the upper levels 1 and 2.'

column59: Ruscinian = Alfambrian MN15 Middle Pliocene.\r\nSite was found during iron mine prospecting in 1966. It is a karst deposit in Jurassic magnesiferous limestones.
column73: red karst deposit.
column94: Deposits full of bones jaws and teeth of small vertebrates and some bones of large mammals and pieces of stalagmites.
column103: The mine prospcetors hole was enlarged to 5x4x4 metres and some bones were recovered during this excavation in 1967 Later excavations from 1972 onwards were conducted by dividing the site into 2m squares and sieved.\r\nSite discoverd by Aguirre and excavated by Crusafont Aguirre and Michaux.

column41: 2km south of the village Motilleja on the lefthand side of the valley of the River Jucar.
column59: Upper Pliocene MN16b.
column103: Gazella borbonica and Equus stenonis make up the majority of the fauna - over 500 specimens.

column41: "the Lakhuti Outcrop is situated north-east of Kuliab on the right bank of the Obimasar river near Lakhuti village". Thre Lakhuti 2 localities are at the mouth od the Khoshar brook a tributary of teh Obimasar. Lakhuti 2 main is along the brook on the left bank.
column59: "the mammal remains originate from the silty inter-layers of the pebble-silty deposists of teh Kayrubak suite". At Lakhuti 2 main the bones are "associated with brown inter-layers of calcareous water-lain silts". "The pebble-silts of the Kayrubak formation are 13-14m thick here. They lie above the Jaramillo event and below the Brunhes/Matuyama boundary" (ie. between 1.0-0.78Ma). Lenticular accumulations of bones are found from the waterline to 2m above it and can be traced 60-70m along the bank.
column60: At Lakhuti 2 main the bones are "associated with brown inter-layers of calcareous water-lain silts which replaces the grey-green silts of the preceding locality" (Lakhuti 2 point). "The pebble-silts of the Kayrubak formation are 13-14m thick here. They lie above the Jaramillo event and below the Brunhes/Matuyama boundary" (ie. between 1.0-0.78Ma). The lenticular accumulations of bones are found from the waterline to 2m above it and can be traced 60-70m along the bank.
column73: Bones are found in the Kayrubak suite which unconformably overlies Lower Pliocene red sandstones and underlies thick Pleistocene loesses containing many fossil soil horizons.
column94: The lenticular accumulations of bones are found from the waterline to 2m above it and can be traced 60-70m along the bank. "They include fragments of skulls jaws and limb-bones sometimes in natural articulation. The bones are yellowish-white with traces of ferrugination"
column103: Fossils were discovered in the 1950s and excavated from 1968 onwards by the Physics Institute the Geological Institute and the Palaeontological Institute the USSR Academy of Sciences and the Institute of Zoology and Parasitology the TajikSSR Academy of Sciences.
column104: "Among these mammalian remains carnivores are abundant in species number and cervids are abundant in the quantity of their remains"

column34: Liventsovka Khapry Formation Sea of Azov\r\nLiventzovka
column41: In the Khapry sand-shingle deposits in the coastal zone of the sea of Azov near Rostov-on-Don (Rostov-na-Donu) on which the co-ordinates are based.
column59: Late Pliocene Middle Villafranchian lower part of MN17 (based on small mammals associated with macrofauna in the lowest levels).\r\nBones largely found in the lower part of the alluvial sequence but some isolated specimens occur higher in the sequence at Liventsovka. Several beds with small mammals occur within the 20m thick sequence.\r\nLiventsovka was a quarry.
column60: Sand-shingle deposits.
column73: Sand-shingle deposits along the coastal zone of the Sea of Azov. 'They unconformably overlie the marine Miocene sediments and correspond to alluvium of an ancient 30-40m terrace of the Don River.'
column103: Collecting began in 1932 from a quarry.\r\nSpecimens held at Rostov State University Rostov-on-Don (RGU) Vernadskii State Geological Museum (GGM) Rostov Regional Museum (RRM) and the Geological Institute Russian Academy of Sciences (GIN).\r\nbpnes are 'strongly mineralised'.
column104: small from of Libralces.

column41: Approximately 2km southeast of the town of Cunchillos (on which the co-ordinates are based) and 5km east of the town of Tarazona de Aragon.

column41: Co-ordinates based on the town of Escobosa de Calatañazor.
column59: Middle Miocene.

column32: Nivel Y Los Valles de Fuentiduenya (Segovia)
column34: Nivel Y Los Valles de Fuentidueña (Segovia)
column41: 1.5km East of the village of Los Valles de Fuentidueña in a small valley next to the hill 'El Coculillo'.
column59: Miocene MN9-10. There are 5 levels with fossil remains level X is the highest in the section (approximately 100m above level Y3).
column60: The majority of nivel Y (Y0-2) fall within levels 3 and 4. Level 3: 'Conglomerado de cantos de caliza y huesos muy dispersos en la matriz. Cierta tendencia al tendido horizontal en los huesos aunque en conjunto l estratificacion presenta un caracter masivo. La matriz arcillosa de color verde grisaceo. Estructura masiva. Los huesos largos muy rotos con predominio de los de eje mayor horizontal. Potencia 40centimetros. Observable por todo el corte. Level 4: ' Arenas de cuarzo con cemento calcareo que pasan a techo a caliza porosa blanquecina con gasteropodo. A techo este nival se encuentra erosionado y ligeramente carstificado. Potencia irregular 10-30 centrimetros.' P. 348.
column73: A pond system with a little alluvial fan in which most of the bones have been found.
column103: Excavations in 1978-79 recovered 1.400kgs of sediment for level Y.

column41: Site is approximately 1km south of the village of Goldra de Baixo (on which the co-ordinates are based) 3km south of the town of Loule.
column59: Late Pleistocene not older than Riss-Wurm possibly first interstadial of the Wurm. Tools are Middle and Upper Paleolithic (Epipaleolithic) - but rather 'uncharacteristic' artefacts.
column60: 'bone breccia'
column73: 'infilling of a karst depression.'
column94: 'frequently burnt bone scraps much broken and with acute edges (no transport) certain debris of human food.'
column103: 8 stone tools made of quartzite quartz flint and graywacke.
column104: Climate indicated is dry similar to current climate. All species in faunal list are still extant in this area.

column41: Near Filakovo in southern central Slovakia just north of the Hungarian border.

column41: Co-ordinates based on the Nestore River near Perugia. The site is a lignite mine to the south of Lake Trasimento in the Tavernelle Basin.
column59: Early Pleistocene Early Biharian Farneta faunal unit Latest Villafranchian. There are three separate lignite mine workings but the levels are thought to be the roughly the same date based on the macro- and micromammalian remains.
column73: swampy environment.
column94: The small mammal remains are eroded suggesting bone collection by a predator.
column103: The specimens were collcetd from an active lignite mine as and when they were found. The material is stored in a small museum on the site.
column104: The dominance of arvicolids nay suggest an environment chracaterised locally by open areas with a cold climate. This hypothesis is further strengthened by the presence of the giant deer Megaceroides obscurus. Mimomys savini has been reported previously but this is thought to have been the mis-identification of a large Mimomys chalinei upper M1.

column41: Site is approximately 10km East of the captial city Kabul (on which the co-ordinates are based).
column59: Early Pliocene Early Ruscinian.
column103: Material excavated in 1978 rodent and lagomorph specimens archived at l'Institut de Paleontolgie MNHN Paris and the University of Montpellier.
column104: Micromammal faunal list indicates an open steppe habitat or herbaceous savanna with gallery forests.

column32: Daodi B Yangyuan county Hebei Province
column41: Co-ordinates based on Yangyuan County.
column59: MN16 Late Pliocene early Youhian Early Villafranchian 'Daodi Fauna'. Specimens recovered from the bottom of the 'Nihewan beds'.
column103: Material recovered by wet sieving in 1984. A total of 3 tons of sediment from 8 sites was sieved for micromammal remains.
column104: The Daodi faunal list from PBD collection 13486 is a composite for all localities. The large mammals Proboscidipparion sinense ?Chilotherium sp. Axis shansius Cervus sp. and Antilospira sp. are associated with the Daodi fauna but are not subdivided by locality.

column41: Co-ordinates based on the city of Angouleme the site is 20km North East of the city on a tributary of the Charente called the Tardoire.
column59: There are five members at this site ranging in age from the Middle to Upper Pleistocene. Members 1-3 (beds I-V) are Middle Pleistocene levels. The Upper Pleistocene is represented by Members 4-5 (beds 10-5). The macromammal fauna is subdivided into groups 1-3 (macromammal group 3 is only found in bed 10). Suggested date for bed 10 is OIS 5d temperate phase.
column60: clays and silts with stones and coproliths.
column94: bifacial stone tools in bed 10. Probably a hyaena den.
column103: This material is still under study.

column32: La grotte de l'Escale bed H Saint-Esteve-Janson Bouches du Rhone.
column41: Near the village of Saint-Esteve-Janson found during the building of the canal EDF in 1960.
column59: Middle Pleistocene (Biharian) roughly 0.8-0.7Ma. \r\nThere are a number of beds within the cave - from A (lowermost)-L (topmost) not all of which contain fauna. Each faunal level has been entered separately.
column60: Fauna comes from bed H. Beds H,I,J are described together are 3 to 5m deep and consist of fallen rocks gravels and pebbles with very indurated? (tres indures) aeolian silts and slabs of limestone corresponding to a harsh climate (tres rigoureux). There is abundant evidence of frost action and loessic inputs.
column103: Specimens held in the Maison Mediterraneenne des Sciences de l'Homme (MMSH) Aix-en-Provence.\r\nBirds are mentioned but not listed. The small mammal remains have been subdivided into collectiosn within beds G and H and these are not directly related to the macromammal remains. They have been entered here at Bed level (i.e. a composite list) see Bonifay 1973 for the breakdown within beds.
column104: Macrofauna indicative of a cold environment. The rodents are indicative of a cold and steppic environment.

column32: La grotte de l'Escale bed G Saint-Esteve-Janson Bouches du Rhone.

column59: Middle Pleistocene (Biharian) roughly 0.8-0.7Ma. \r\nThere are a number of beds within the cave - from A (lowermost)-L (topmost) not all of which contain fauna. Each faunal level has been entered separately.
column60: Fauna comes from bed G which consists of deteriorated (altere) fallen rocks of a reddish colour lacustrine limestones travertines with seeds of Celtis and stalagmite floors. Total thickness between 1.5-3 metres.

Rodents in level G and H are subsampled within the beds but these divisions are not related to the macromammals. Therefore the composite list for the bed has been entered here. For subdivisions within beds see Bonifay 1973.
column104: Fauna indicative of a temperate environment - macrofauna indicates warm and dry conditions the cold environment rodents in level H have disappeared and seeds of Celtis are very abundant.

column41: Co-ordinates are based on Dijon the site is near here (estimated from map in Fig 1 Bonifay 1973).
column59: Biharian. Gunz or most ancient Mindel glaciation. Complex stratigraphy (see collection info).
column103: Complex stratigraphy with several climatic changes documented. Cycles 1 2 3 and 5 correspond with temperate more or less wet phases while 4 and 6 are indicative of cold continental climates with cycle 4 marking the maximum cold phase.
column104: Also marked on the list is M. malei-burgondiaes nov. ssp. The genus is not clearly indicated - could be Mimomys - but it has been omitted from the entered taxonomic list.

column41: Co-ordinates based on the nearby town of Sant'Arcangelo. Site is between the main rivers of Sauro and Agri near the Rifreddo and S. Lorenzo streams.
column59: Early Middle Pleistocene Late Biharian.
column60: 'peaty clay'. There are three layers with vertebrate remains interspersed with volcaniclastic (tephra) horizons within a 3m section. The faunal lists have not been subdivided into these layers in this publication. All layers are described as 'peaty-clays.'
column73: Sant'Arcangelo Basin 'filled by a silicalastic sequence 3500m thick dated to the Late Pliocene-Middle Pleistocene.' In this basin an Early Middle Pleistocene fluvial lacustrine sequence (the San Lorenzo cycle) has been recognised. In teh upper part a short sequence of alternating thin coal and volcanoclastic beds is exposed. The organic rich levels contain fishes amphibians reptiles and a fairly diversified micro-mammal assemblage.
column103: Molluscs and vegetational remains are mentioned but not listed. Levels uncovered in field investigations in 1998 and screen sieved for fossils.

column41: Co-ordinates based on Abingdon. The locality was discovered during the building of the Abingdon Bypass and is SW of Oxford.
column59: Cromerian pre-zone Cr IV probably pollen zone Cr IIIb. Younger than West Runton. Late Lower to Early Middle Pleistocene. Three samples were taken from this horizon (B) which is the second lowest in the sequence approximately 0.5m thick and 1.5m above the arbitrary base level.
column60: Samples of sediment taken from horizons with seams of sands gravels and detritus muds.
column94: 'the terrestrial material was for the most part probably disarticulated and broken by the activities of predators and by transport in the river.' The Sugworth fossil material comprises isolated bones and teeth many of which are fragmentary. Most are the most resistant portions of the skeleton e.g. teeth caudal vertebrae and anterior portions of rodent mandibles.
column103: 16 samples each weighing 20kg were taken from 6 different horizons. Three samples were taken from this horizon.

column41: Central Rhineland close to the confluence of the Rhine and Moselle. The site is on a small spur of land on the eastern bank of the Nette Stream.
column59: Oldest Arvicola cantianus fauna Middle Middle Pleistocene Latest Cromerian - correlated with interglacial IV roughly 0.4Ma. Material has been collected from a variety of units but for the mammals they are all regarded as the same faunal unit. Several specimens in units G and F refit together. Mollusca have been subdivided but are not given here.
column103: Mollusca collected but not listed here. Site discovered after pumice extraction in 1982 and excavated between 1982 and 1990.
column104: Mammalian faunal list for all levels.

column60: Fossiliferous silts and sands.
column73: From a broad channel of fossiliferous silts and sands. Temperate climate regional vegetation of mixed deciduous woodland extensive dry grassland in the river floodplain and swampy areas near the river.
column94: Taphonomic data not reviewed in paper
column103: Material taken from boreholes and pits. First found in 1939. 50kg bulk samples were taken from successive grabs 25cm thick to a depth of 350cm amounting to 1.5 tons of sediment and wet sieved through 1cm and 1mm sieves. All material is held at the University Museum of Zoology Cambrige with a small amount at the BMNH in London.
column104: Definitely not representative; may include plant and non-invertebrate macrofossils. Based on taxa listed on p. 17

column32: Karlich level G im Neuwieder Becken
column34: Kärlich Schicht G im Neuwieder Becken\r\nKaerlich
column41: in the southwestern Neuwied Basin.
column59: Level G is towards the top of the sequence (site goes level Jb). Middle Middle Pleistocene Arvicola cantianus Cromerian interglacial III roughly 500,000BP.
column60: loess.
column73: There are two levels Ga and Gb both are loess with a hiatus between them and two levels of basalt tuff.
column103: Sparse mollusc fauna indicative of cold climatic conditions and a rather humid environment. Over 2,500 identifiable micromammal specimens have been collected after processing several tons of sediment.
column104: There are two levels Ga and Gb but the micromammal mollusca and macrofauna are not subdivided with the exception of Equus sp. and cervidae indet. in Ga both of which are found in Gb as well.

column32: Fissure 6 Quarry 3 Monte Tuttavista Orosei Sardinia
column41: A series of 19 fissure fillings over an area of approximately 3km southwest of Orosei (on which the co-ordinates are based) on the eastern side of Monte Tuttavista along the area of Canale Longu Oroe and Santa Rughe.
column59: Probably Early Pleistocene within the localities this is known as the 'nesogoral complex' and cosnsistes of VI 3 X ghiro VII VII blocco strada and VII mustelide. However an earlier Late Pliocene date cannot be ruled out.
column60: Fissures contain various detrital sediments ranging from fossil breccias to dark clays. Different depositional events can be distinguished in some of the larger fissures/cavities.
column73: Monte Tuttavista is 836m a.s.l. and is formed of Mesozoic limestones. Dissolution has formed a network of fissures which are mainly narrow and coincident with fracture lineaments.
column103: Specimens are held at the Operating Office of the Soprintendenza per Beni Archeologici in Nuoro and in the Archaeological Museum of Nuoro. \r\nLocalities found in 1995 this paper (ref. 13691) reports on work from 1996-2003.
column104: Only 1 Caprinae new genus new species present.

column32: Fissure 10 3 Uccelli Quarry Monte Tuttavista Orosei Sardinia
column41: A series of 19 fissure fillings over an area of approximately 3km southwest of Orosei (on which the co-ordinates are based) on the eastern side of Monte Tuttavista along the area of Canale Longu Oroe and Santa Rughe.
column59: Latest Early Pleistocene/ Early Middle Pleistocene. A new faunal complex with ancestral species prior to the classic 'Praemegaceros-Tyrrhenicola' complex and only represented by two sites - X3 Uccelli and X mele.
column60: Fissures contain various detrital sediments ranging from fossil breccias to dark clays. Different depositional events can be distinguished in some of the larger fissures/cavities.

column32: Fissure 11 canide Quarry Monte Tuttavista Orosei Sardinia
column41: A series of 19 fissure fillings over an area of approximately 3km southwest of Orosei (on which the co-ordinates are based) on the eastern side of Monte Tuttavista along the area of Canale Longu Oroe and Santa Rughe.
column59: Middle-Late Pleistocene. A new faunal complex subdivided into primitive (earlier) 'Praemegaceros-Tyrrhenicola' complex and a later one. This is the earlier and comprises the following fissures - XI canide XI dic.2001 XI Mar 2002 XI 3 XI rondone. IX Prolagus XI 3 IV 5 and IV 20 appear to form a slightly earlier subgroup.
column60: Fissures contain various detrital sediments ranging from fossil breccias to dark clays. Different depositional events can be distinguished in some of the larger fissures/cavities.

column32: Fissure 11 dic.2001 Monte Tuttavista Orosei Sardinia
column41: A series of 19 fissure fillings over an area of approximately 3km southwest of Orosei (on which the co-ordinates are based) on the eastern side of Monte Tuttavista along the area of Canale Longu Oroe and Santa Rughe.
column59: Middle-Late Pleistocene. A new faunal complex subdivided into primitive (earlier) 'Praemegaceros-Tyrrhenicola' complex and a later one. This is the earlier and comprises the following fissures - XI canide XI dic.2001 XI Mar 2002 XI 3 XI rondone. IX Prolagus XI 3 IV 5 and IV 20 appear to form a slightly earlier subgroup.
column60: Fissures contain various detrital sediments ranging from fossil breccias to dark clays. Different depositional events can be distinguished in some of the larger fissures/cavities.
column73: Monte Tuttavista is 836m a.s.l. and is formed of Mesozoic limestones. Dissolution has formed a network of fissures which are mainly narrow and coincident with fracture lineaments.
column103: Specimens are held at the Operating Office of the Soprintendenza per Beni Archeologici in Nuoro and in the Archaeological Museum of Nuoro. \r\nLocalities found in 1995 this paper (ref. 13691) reports on work from 1996-2003.

column32: Monte La Mesa near Rivoli Veronese Verona northeastern Italy
column41: The site is in a quarry on the southern side of the Monte La Mesa south of Rivoli Veronese village facing east toward the Ceraino Gorge (in which the River Adige flows).
column59: Early Biharian early/middle Early Pleistocene older than Pietrafitta and Pirro Nord similar age to Zabia Cave Osztramos 8 and Betfia 10. Date based on presence of Microtus (Allophaiomys) gr. pliocaenicus plus Mimomys tornensis and M. pusillus. Possibly correlates with Waalian A.
column60: Diaclase.
column73: Karst fissure.
column94: Some teeth corroded and lack cement possibly due to a forested environment.
column103: Site discovered in 1996. Sediments washed to recover small vertebrates.
column104: Forest rodents and insectivores predominate suggesting a wooded environment. A wet and temperate phase following an arid phase during which Microtus (Allophaiomys) spread across the Holarctic. Probably correlates with Waalian A.

column41: Site is near Siena (on which the co-ordinates are based).
column59: Late Villanyian Early Pleistocene.
column60: Lower part of the cave contains terra rossa friabile. There is also some more compact breccia.
column103: Friable Terra rossa sieved through 1 to 0.5mm sieves. Hardened breccia dissolved using 85% 'acido formico'. Material held in the Instituto di Geologia e Paleontologia di Siena with some in the private collections of F. Filippini and G. Maccherini.

column41: Fischbach 600m Helsighausen Municipality Thurgau Canton;\ngeocoordinates: 721800/277800
column59: MN7 about 13.5 Mill. years
column60: Lime-sandy shellphragments of molluscs 5 cm thick sediment layer
column103: Except the very big fossils all the teeth has been collected by sieving of 300 kg.

column41: near the town of Gray\n"1.8-2.0 ha"
column59: "4.5 to 7 Myr (late Miocene to early Pliocene" (meaning late Hemphillian to early Blancan)
column60: "highly laminated organic laden silty sediments" (Wallace et al. 2002)\r\n"finely laminated clays silts and fine sands intermixed with isolated gravel lenses that fill a former sinkhole... up to 39 m thick... result of a small lake or pond that formed within the sinkhole" (Wallace and Wang 2004)
